scenarios.title: Emailing Your Teacher
scenarios.situation: You need to ask for a deadline extension because you've been ill.

options.text: Hey Mr. Smith, can I get more time?
problems: Using 'Hey' is too informal for a teacher

options.text: Dear Mr. Smith, I would like to request an extension on the assignment due to illness. Could we discuss this? Best regards, [Name]
Yo teach, I was sick so I need more time k?

feedback.correct: Perfect! You used appropriate formal language, explained the reason clearly, showed respect with 'Dear' and proper closing, and opened discussion rather than demanding.
feedback.incorrect: Too casual for a teacher email. Teachers expect formal communication. Use 'Dear [Name]', explain your situation politely, make a request (not demand), and always close formally with your name.

teaching_points: Always use 'Dear [Teacher Name]' for teachers
Explain WHY you need something
Use polite request language: 'Would it be possible...', 'I would like to request...'
Close with 'Best regards' or 'Sincerely' + your full name
Proofread for spelling and grammar

scenarios.title: Job Application Email
scenarios.situation: You're applying for a part-time position at a local bookstore.

options.text: Hi! I saw your job ad and I'm interested!
problems: 'Hi!' is too casual for job applications

options.text: Dear Hiring Manager, I am writing to express my interest in the part-time position advertised. I have attached my CV for your consideration. I would welcome the opportunity to discuss my application further. Sincerely, [Full Name]
Hey, got any jobs going? Let me know

feedback.correct: Excellent! You demonstrated professionalism with proper greeting, stated your purpose clearly, mentioned the CV attachment (crucial!), showed enthusiasm for next steps, and used a formal closing with your full name. This is exactly how job applications should look.
feedback.incorrect: Way too informal for a job application. Employers receive dozens of applications - yours needs to stand out as professional. Always use 'Dear Hiring Manager', clearly state which position you're applying for, mention your CV attachment, and close formally.

teaching_points: Use 'Dear Hiring Manager' if you don't have a specific name
State which position you're applying for in the first sentence
Mention that you've attached your CV/resume
Briefly highlight one relevant qualification
Express interest in an interview
Use 'Sincerely' or 'Best regards' + your full name
Include contact information in your signature

scenarios.title: Emailing a Friend
scenarios.situation: You're inviting your friend to hang out this weekend.

options.text: Dear Sarah, I hope this email finds you well. I would like to formally invite you to spend time together this weekend at your earliest convenience. Kind regards, [Name]
problems: Way too formal for a friend

options.text: Hey Sarah! Want to hang out this weekend? Let me know! üòä
strengths: Sounds like how friends actually talk

options.text: TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN: Saturday meeting request
problems: Way too formal for any friend
Would confuse or amuse your friend

feedback.correct: Perfect! Casual and friendly tone is exactly right for emails to friends. Using 'Hey', being direct, and even adding an emoji is totally fine with friends. This is how people actually talk to each other!
feedback.incorrect: Way too formal for a friend! When emailing friends, you can be casual - use 'Hey', emojis are fine, and just talk naturally. Save the formal language for teachers, employers, and people you don't know well. Your friends will think you're being weird if you're too formal!

teaching_points: With friends, be yourself and use your normal voice
Casual greetings like 'Hey' or 'Hi' are perfect
Emojis are totally fine with friends
You don't need formal closings
Keep it short and natural
The goal is communication, not impressing them with formality

scenarios.title: Doctor's Appointment
scenarios.situation: You need to book an appointment with your doctor.

options.text: yo doc need to see u asap
Dear Dr. [Name], I would like to schedule an appointment at your earliest convenience. Please let me know available times. Thank you, [Your Full Name]
Hey can I come in sometime?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Medical professionals expect professional communication. You used their proper title (Dr.), made a clear request, showed flexibility with 'at your earliest convenience', and closed professionally with your full name.
feedback.incorrect: Medical professionals expect polite, professional communication. Always use their proper title (Dr. [Name]), make clear requests, and be specific about what you need. This is healthcare - treat it seriously.

teaching_points: Always use professional titles: Dr., Professor, etc.
Be specific about what you need
Medical contexts require formal language
Include your full name (they have many patients)
If it's urgent, explain why (but don't just say 'urgent')
Close with 'Thank you' and your full name

scenarios.title: University Admissions
scenarios.situation: You're inquiring about an application you submitted two weeks ago.

options.text: Dear Admissions Office, I submitted my application for the Computer Science program on December 28th (Application ID: 12345). I am writing to respectfully inquire about the status of my application. I remain very interested in attending your institution. Thank you for your time and consideration. Sincerely, [Full Name], [Email], [Phone]
Hey guys, just checking on my app, let me know!

feedback.correct: Outstanding! This is exactly how to handle formal inquiries. You provided all necessary information (date, program, ID), used respectful language, reaffirmed your interest, and maintained perfect professional tone throughout. University admissions officers appreciate this level of professionalism.
feedback.incorrect: University communications require the highest level of formality. These are important decision-makers evaluating you. Always use formal greetings, provide specific details (date, program, ID number), use respectful inquiry language, and close with complete contact information.

teaching_points: Universities expect very formal communication
Always provide: Application ID, date submitted, program name
Use 'inquire' not 'ask' or 'wondering'
Show continued interest in the institution
Include complete contact information
Proofread multiple times - this is crucial
Consider having someone else review before sending

scenarios.title: Customer Service Complaint
scenarios.situation: A product you ordered arrived damaged and you want a refund.

options.text: This is ridiculous!!! I want my money back NOW!!!
problems: Likely to be ignored or deprioritized

options.text: Dear Customer Service, I am writing regarding Order #67890 placed on January 5th. The product arrived damaged (see attached photos). I am disappointed as I had high expectations for your company. I would like to request a full refund or replacement. Please advise on the next steps. Thank you, [Name]
hey so like the thing i ordered is kinda broken... idk what to do?
problems: Too casual for a business request

feedback.correct: Excellent! You struck the perfect balance: firm about the problem but professional in tone. You provided all necessary details (order number, date, evidence), stated your desired resolution clearly, and maintained politeness while being assertive. This approach gets results.
feedback.incorrect: When dealing with customer service, be firm but professional. Provide specific details (order number, date), describe the problem clearly, suggest a solution, and maintain a respectful tone. Anger and vagueness don't get refunds - clear, professional communication does.

teaching_points: Be firm but not aggressive
Always include order number and date
Describe problem clearly and objectively
Attach evidence (photos, receipts)
State desired resolution (refund, replacement)
Set reasonable timeline expectations
Keep emotions in check - professionalism gets better results
